Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Utilizing Collaborative Event Ethnography to Understand Global Environmental Governance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project uses an innovative methodology called collaborative event ethnography to advance understanding of contemporary global environmental governance. Focusing on a case study of the 2016 World Conservation Congress, the project examines how notions of the "green economy", such as those inscribed in the UNEP-led Green Economy Initiative, are shaping global environmental conservation practices. As part of a coordinated effort among researchers from multiple universities, countries, and disciplines, the project strengthens multi-national research, training, and teaching partnerships in producing policy-relevant scientific research. It integrates research and education through cascade mentoring, which includes senior and junior scholars and graduate and undergraduate students, from two liberal arts colleges and a large research university in the development of innovative methodology and theory-building in global environmental governance. Through rigorous theoretical and methodological training for graduate and undergraduate students, the project helps them to develop the skills and knowledge to apply geographic concepts and methods to pressing global environmental issues, while simultaneously exposing them to potential careers in environmental research and policy. By illuminating the complexities of how actors influence global environmental governance, it reveals avenues for redressing seemingly intractable environmental crises and global inequality at a critical historical moment.

The project challenges state-centric understandings of global environmental governance and advances new theories about how contemporary governance occurs. It augments traditional field-based studies of conservation with ethnographic data in order to trace how paradigm shifts occur in global conservation politics. Specifically, the project analyzes how global conservation governance transpires across multiple institutional sites by focusing on international conferences as key venues in which diverse actors, who are normally dispersed in time and space, convene to negotiate. It attends to the types of strategies that diverse actors use and the ways in which conference norms, structures, forms of acceptable knowledge and measurement shape the ways in which these actors interact and influence negotiations, revealing how and why certain actors are better able than others to catalyze paradigm shifts. Ultimately, it documents how paradigm shifts occur not only through official discourse, policy and law, but also through more informal, everyday interactions among public, private and non-profit actors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has used and further developed an innovative methodology called Collaborative Event Ethnography (CEE) to advance our understanding of global environmental governance. CEE involves teams of researchers who conduct research at large international events, collaborating on all aspects of the research process from research design to analysis and writing. The team studies formal and informal processes of policy making, ranging from orchestrated announcements and high-profile negotiations to the more mundane, daily practices of policy-making, focusing on the ways in which actors draw on particular ideas and narratives to build alliances in support of their policy goals and objectives. 

Methodologically, we have shown that benefits associated with strong collaborative fieldwork include: robust, collective interpretation of embodied data that makes room for different theoretical framings; intellectual and social support and professional development for individual researchers, particularly junior and female scholars, and those from underrepresented groups. We have developed mechanisms to address the challenges of collaborative ethnography such as: managing team dynamics related to seniority, gender, and disciplinary training; using protocols for data sharing, collaborative analysis, and authorship on outputs; valuing and recognizing individual contributions in equitable ways that also accord with professional and institutional expectations and norms. Overall, we assert that strong collaborative approaches to fieldwork, like CEE, cultivate innovative knowledge production.

Drawing on insights generated from these conferences and individual field sites across the globe, we have traced the constitutive forces behind paradigm shifts in biodiversity conservation, focusing primarily on the interconnected rise of market-based approaches, the role of targets-based governance, and the struggle to recognize human rights in conservation, as well as the increasing influence of nonstate--private and nonprofit--actors in global conservation governance. We have shown, theoretically, how distributed power dynamics across diverse organizations shape political outcomes, and specifically, how actors have built alliances and negotiated compromises by using both formal rules and procedures and informal mechanisms to promote particular agendas. Using specific issues, such as human rights discourse, targets-based governance, and the economization of conservation, as lenses into broader governance processes, we have analyzed how and why particular agendas advance in conservation. For example, Campbell and Gray draw on negotiations and debates at the WCC and prior events to problematize targets-based governance, arguing that marine protected areas targets have become a ?privileged solution? in marine conservation because their expansion is relatively easy to measure and because they afford opportunities for further expansion in the mostly unprotected global ocean. Similarly, Corson et al. have shown how the meetings such as the WCC provide a platform for advancing rights-based conservation approaches. However, the translation of the human rights agenda into action ?on the ground? remains weak. Finally, Wilshusen illustrates how new techniques of conservation governance draw on the language and practices of economics to bring together business and biodiversity organizations. 

As a collaboration among researchers from multiple universities, countries, and disciplines, the project has strengthened multi-national research, training, and teaching partnerships in producing policy-relevant research. It has integrated research and education by using cascade mentoring, which has included senior and junior scholars, as well as graduate and undergraduate students, from two liberal arts colleges and three large research universities. Through rigorous methodological and theoretical training for students, it has helped them to develop the skills and knowledge to apply geography concepts and methods to pressing contemporary and future global issues, while simultaneously exposing them to potential careers in environmental research and policy. Finally, by illuminating the complexities of how actors influence global environmental governance, it has also revealed avenues for redressing seemingly intractable environmental crises and global inequality at a critical historical moment.
